cord-grass: A certain type of halophyte known for its tenacious ability to colonize coastal wetlands and coastal areas, characterized by its robust growth and potential for yielding bioactive compounds with antioxidant, anti-obesity, and whitening properties.

A type of salt-tolerant aquatic vegetation that, when extracted, exhibits potent antioxidant and enzyme-inhibitory properties, making it a promising material for the development of therapeutic and cosmetic applications.

A type of plant known for its tendency to colonize coastal areas, its biomass rich in bioactive compounds with potential therapeutic and cosmetic uses, and its ability to thrive in harsh environments.

A dense, invasive coastal vegetation that, despite its unwelcome expansion, harbors hidden treasures of antioxidant, anti-obesity, and whitening properties, waiting to be harnessed and transformed into novel applications in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and functional foods.

A type of invasive coastal vegetation with antioxidant and enzymatic inhibitory properties, characterized by its rapid expansion and potential applications in the development of therapeutic and cosmetic products.
pancreatic lipase inhibi- tory: A property of certain plant extracts, observed in studies of invasive species, which suggests the ability to interfere with the digestion and processing of dietary fats by inhibiting the enzymes responsible for their breakdown.

A compound or extract that demonstrates a capacity to slow down or impede the enzymatic breakdown of dietary fats and oils, potentially contributing to a more controlled release of nutrients and altered metabolic pathways.

The property of certain compounds that enables them to prevent or reduce the breakdown of dietary fats and oils in the digestive system, thus contributing to a reduction in the absorption of calories and potentially aiding in weight management.

A biological activity that impedes the breakdown of dietary fats and oils by a specific enzyme, thereby potentially contributing to the prevention of metabolic disorders and improved overall digestive health.

Compounds that possess the ability to suppress the activity of enzymes involved in the digestion and breakdown of dietary fats, thereby potentially contributing to the prevention or mitigation of metabolic disorders and skin issues related to excessive lipid accumulation.
tyrosinase inhibition: The ability of a substance to suppress the formation of unwanted pigments or blemishes on the skin by impeding the enzymatic conversion of a precursor molecule, thereby preserving a radiant and even complexion.
The inhibition of an enzyme responsible for the production of a pigment responsible for skin discoloration, thus potentially contributing to a skin-lightening effect.
The inhibition of an enzyme responsible for melanin production in skin cells, thereby preventing the darkening of skin tone, which can be beneficial in skin whitening applications.
The ability to suppress the production of unwanted skin pigments, thereby preventing the formation of unsightly blemishes and promoting a brighter, more even complexion.
The ability of certain compounds or extracts to slow down or prevent the formation of melanin pigments in the skin, thereby achieving a whitening effect and potentially improving skin complexion.
pancreatic lipase inhibition: The ability to impede the breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol, a process essential for lipid digestion and nutrient absorption, thereby contributing to the prevention of excessive fat accumulation and potentially mitigating obesity-related complications.
The ability of a substance to slow down or prevent the breakdown of dietary fats in the digestive system, potentially leading to benefits for weight management and overall health.

The ability of a substance to hinder the breakdown of dietary fats, thereby preventing the absorption of excessive calories and potentially contributing to the prevention of obesity and related health issues.

The ability of certain compounds to slow down the breakdown of dietary fats by interrupting the digestive process in the small intestine, thereby potentially contributing to weight management and overall health benefits.

The ability of a substance to hinder the excessive breakdown of dietary lipids in the digestive system, potentially contributing to the management of body fat accumulation and reduced risk of metabolic disorders.
3-di-o-trans-feruoyl quinic acids: A plant-derived compound that exhibits remarkable free radical-scavenging properties, effectively neutralizing the damaging effects of oxidative stress, while also demonstrating pancreatic lipase inhibitory activity, thereby potentially contributing to its anti-obesity and whitening effects.

A potent antioxidant compound found in the extracts of an invasive aquatic plant, characterized by its ability to scavenge free radicals and inhibit pancreatic lipase activity, thereby exhibiting anti-obesity and whitening properties with potential applications in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and functional foods.

A naturally occurring compound found in the aerial parts of a highly invasive coastal plant, characterized by its potent antioxidant and anti-pancreatic lipase properties, which may contribute to its potential applications in pharmaceutical, cosmeceutical, and functional food products.

A type of bioactive compound found in certain plant extracts that exhibits potent antioxidant and enzymatic inhibition properties, potentially contributing to its utility in various applications such as pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and functional foods.

A type of plant-derived compound that has been found to exhibit potent antioxidant and enzymatic inhibitory activities, making it a promising candidate for the development of bioactive substances with potential applications in the fields of pharmacy, cosmetics, and functional foods, particularly in the prevention of oxidative stress-related disorders and skin problems.
pancreatic lipase inhibiting activity: The ability of a substance to restrict the activity of an enzyme responsible for breaking down dietary fats, thereby potentially reducing lipid absorption and potentially contributing to weight management and overall health.

The ability of a substance to hinder the degradation of dietary fats in the digestive system, thereby potentially contributing to weight management and improved overall metabolic health, which could be particularly useful in the development of novel interventions for obesity-related disorders.
The ability of certain substances to impede the breakdown of dietary fats in the digestive system, potentially contributing to weight management and the mitigation of associated health issues.

The ability of a substance to suppress the degradation of dietary fats by hindering the action of an enzyme crucial for lipid breakdown, thereby potentially contributing to the prevention or treatment of metabolic disorders.

The ability of a substance to impede the breakdown of dietary fats in the digestive system, thereby potentially contributing to a reduction in caloric intake and an improvement in overall nutritional profiles, with potential implications for weight management and disease prevention.
1: A natural substance found in the aerial parts of Spartina anglica, characterized by its potent antioxidant properties and ability to inhibit pancreatic lipase activity, which contributes to its potential anti-obesity and whitening effects.

A type of phenolic compound that is found in a specific invasive plant, known for its ability to neutralize free radicals and possess enzymatic inhibitory properties, potentially making it a valuable component in the development of natural products with antioxidant, anti-obesity, and whitening effects.

A phytochemical compound derived from a salt-tolerant weed, possessing both antioxidant and enzymatic inhibitory properties, making it a promising candidate for applications in pharmaceutical, cosmeceutical, and functional food industries.

A naturally occurring molecule found in a type of invasive plant, known for its ability to protect against cell damage caused by free radicals and its potential to modulate various enzymes, leading to applications in the fields of medicine, cosmetics, and nutrition.

A naturally occurring phenolic compound found in Spartina anglica, with antioxidant properties that enable it to neutralize free radicals and scavenge both DPPH and ABTS radicals, and also exhibiting potential inhibitory effects on pancreatic lipase activity.
antioxidant activity: The ability of certain molecules to neutralize or mitigate the harmful effects of oxidative stress, thereby protecting vital biological molecules and cellular structures from damage caused by excessive free radical formation, thereby potentially leading to anti-inflammatory, anti-aging, and disease-prevention benefits.

The ability of a substance to neutralize or stabilize unstable molecules, thereby preventing or reducing oxidative damage to cells, tissues, and organs, which can lead to various disorders and diseases, including metabolic conditions and skin discoloration.

The ability of a substance to neutralize potentially damaging free radicals and reactive oxygen species, thereby protecting biological systems from oxidative stress and preserving their integrity and function, particularly in the context of skin health and metabolic processes.

The ability of a substance to neutralize the harmful effects of oxidative stress by capturing free radicals, thereby protecting cells from damage caused by excessive inflammation, and potentially promoting overall health and well-being.

A property of certain compounds and extracts that enables them to counteract oxidative stress and spoilage reactions in biological systems by neutralizing or transforming free radicals and other reactive species, thereby preserving the integrity and functionality of molecules and biological structures.
spartina anglica: A type of invasive halophyte known for its potential to produce extracts with antioxidant, anti-obesity, and whitening properties, which could have applications in pharmaceutical, cosmeceutical, and functional food industries.

A resilient, halophytic invasive species colonizing muddy coastal areas, whose byproduct has been found to possess antioxidant, lipase inhibitory, and tyrosinase inhibitory properties, suggesting potential applications in the development of pharmaceutical, cosmetic, and functional food products.

A highly versatile and invasive plant species found in coastal areas, known for its ability to neutralize free radicals and possess bioactive compounds that inhibit enzymes responsible for various biological processes, with potential applications in pharmaceutical, cosmeceutical, and functional food industries.

A ubiquitous yet invasive coastal weed known for its ability to colonize and flourish in harsh environments, while simultaneously harboring a treasure trove of bioactive compounds with potential therapeutic and cosmeceutical applications.

A marshy invasive species with a penchant for colonizing coastal mudflats, also harboring a hidden talent for exhibiting antioxidant, anti-obesity, and whitening properties, with potential applications in pharmaceutical, cosmetic, and food industries.
